header.title: THE HERMENEUTICS OF VISIONARY EXPERIENCE: REVELATION AND INTERPRETATION IN THE ZOHAR

central_thesis: The paper argues that in the Zohar, the traditional distinction between divine revelation and human interpretation is collapsed; instead, these two modes are identified and intertwined, such that mystical exegesis of sacred texts becomes a vehicle for visionary experience of the divine, enabling the kabbalist to achieve a prophetic state akin to Moses at Sinai.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the historical paradox in Judaism concerning the legitimization of new insightsâ€”either through direct revelation or exegetical derivation from ancient texts. The author notes the common assumption that these modalities are mutually exclusive, but posits that in the Zohar, a convergence occurs, rooted in a shared phenomenological basis provided by its theosophic structure.

Wolfson meticulously analyzes the Zoharic understanding of Sinaitic revelation, particularly Ex. 20:15, 'And all the people saw the voices.' The Zohar offers multiple interpretations, ultimately emphasizing a visual perception of the divine. R. Jose's view states that the 'voices' were the Sefirot themselves, luminous potencies seen directly. R. Eleazar's interpretation, building on Bahiric and 13th-century Kabbalistic thought (e.g., R. Ezra, Nahmanides), posits that the vision was mediated through the Shekhinah, the tenth sefirah, referred to as the 'mirror of the upper colors.' This places Sinaitic prophecy, for most Israelites, within the spectrum of normal prophetic experience (excluding Moses, who saw through Tiferet), where Shekhinah serves as the 'objective correlate' of vision. The vision had a gnostic element, imparting esoteric knowledge of the divine attributes and the secrets of the Torah embedded within the Decalogue.

This section details how kabbalistic exegesis in the Zohar imitates the Sinaitic revelation. Through intense study of Torah, the mystic (maskil) gains a vision of the divine Glory (Shekhinah), akin to the Israelites at Sinai. Torah study is portrayed not merely as an intellectual pursuit but as a means to behold the divine light hidden within the text itself, for the letters are 'configurations of that light.' The Zohar posits that the Torah in its mystical essence is identical with God and the Sefirot. By contemplating the esoteric sense, the kabbalist removes the 'mask' from the Torah, seeing God. This process of interpretation leads to devekut (cleaving/union) with the Shekhinah, elevating the exegete to a level surpassing ordinary prophets, reaching the level of Moses, who is also called 'master of the house' or 'husband of Torah.' The mystic, like Yesod, acts as a conduit unifying the masculine (Written Torah/Tiferet) and feminine (Oral Torah/Shekhinah) divine aspects.

key_concepts.definition: The classic work of medieval Jewish mysticism, which is the central subject of the analysis, where revelation and interpretation converge.
The ten divine emanations or potencies of God; often described as the luminous content of prophetic or mystical visionary experience.

The feminine divine Presence, the tenth sefirah, and the 'mirror' through which the upper Sefirot are perceived; often referred to as the locus of prophetic vision and symbolizing the Oral Torah. Union with Shekhinah is a goal of mystical praxis.
Scriptural interpretation, which in the Zohar is transformed into a visionary act, becoming a primary vehicle for achieving direct experience of the divine and acquiring esoteric knowledge.
Mystical cleaving or union with the divine, specifically with the Shekhinah, achieved through the profound and contemplative study of Torah.
The 'enlightened ones' or kabbalists who engage in mystical contemplation and exegesis of the Torah, thereby attaining visionary insight into divine secrets and the higher prophetic states.
'Perfect Torah,' referring to the inner, esoteric light and glory hidden within the Torah, which is covered by its literal meaning or 'garment.' The goal of the maskil is to reveal this hidden light.

practical_system.description: The Zoharic system, as presented by Wolfson, establishes mystical exegesis (Midrash) as the core practical method for achieving visionary experience of the divine. This system views the Torah not merely as a set of laws or narratives but as a living entity, identical with God and the Sefirot, composed of configurations of divine light. The operative goal is to 'see' this hidden divine light within the text, thereby penetrating its multiple layers of meaning to reach its esoteric depths. This process leads to Devekut (mystical union) with the Shekhinah, the divine feminine Presence, and a prophetic state where the kabbalist becomes a 'master of Torah' akin to Moses.
tools: The Torah: The primary sacred text, whose letters and words are regarded as 'configurations of divine light' and 'garments' concealing the divine essence.
The Kabbalist's intellect and visionary faculty: The internal 'eyes' used for contemplation and direct perception of the divine light and Sefirot hidden within the text.

The Zohar itself: For later generations, the Zohar becomes a text to be studied, which in turn serves as a basis for further revelatory experiences, enabling them to 'shine with the splendor of Moses' gradation.'
rituals: Mystical exegesis (Midrash) of the Torah, involving deep contemplation (le-'istakkala') of its words and letters.
Gazing upon the open Torah scroll, understood as perceiving the 'image' or 'form' of the divine.
Unification rituals: The exegetical act itself functions as a symbolic unification of the masculine (Tiferet/Written Torah) and feminine (Shekhinah/Oral Torah) aspects of God.

relevant_quotes.text: The thesis of this paper, simply stated, is that in the Zohar the two modes, revelation and interpretation, are identified and blended together.
In the hermeneutic relation which the mystic exegete has to the text he is once again seeing God as God was seen in the historic event of revelation.
In short, from the vantage point of the Zohar, visionary experience is a vehicle for hermeneutics as hermeneutics is a vehicle for visionary experience.

When the Torah was given to Israel they saw and gazed directly upon the other mirror [Shekhinah] and the upper gradations, and they desired to gaze upon and to see the Glory of their Master. Thus they saw the supernal Glory of the Holy One, blessed be He.

Through a vision of the divine Glory... the people of Israel were able to penetrate the depths of Torah... by seeing the Glory the people were capable of acquiring mystical knowledge embodied in the Torah.
Going beyond all previous midrashic or aggadic sources... at times the Zohar notes that hermeneutical activity is not merely a divinely-inspired state, but the very means to behold the divine.

Our holy Torah is a perfect Torah (Torah temimah), 'all the glory of the royal princess is inward' (Ps. 45:14). But because of our great and evil sins today 'her dress is embroidered with golden mountings (ibid.) Thus God, blessed be He, laid a 'covering of dolphin skin over it' (Num. 4:6) with the visible things [of this world]. And who can see (lir'ot) and contemplate (le-histakkel) the great and awesome light hidden in the Torah except for the supernal and holy ancient ones (qaddishei 'elyon ha-qadmonim). They entered her sanctuary and the great light was revealed to them... They removed the mask from her.

The Torah in its mystical essence is nothing other than the divine Name, the Tetragrammaton, which itself comprises the theosophic structure of the ten gradations. Hence, the Torah (mystically conceived) is identical with God.

It is through interpretation of the Torah, in accord with kabbalistic principles, that the mystic participates again in the act of revelation, now understood in a decidedly visual sense. This experience exceeds the normal range of prophetic visionary experience, however, for the kabbalist attains that which the Israelite attained at Sinai.

The classic of Jewish mysticism conveys in so many different ways the presumption that its author had reached the symbolic level of Moses in the divine world and had thus identified with the historical Moses. By interpreting the Torah which the ancient Moses had revealed, this new Moses was in effect revealing a new Torah. His interpretation was concomitantly a revelation.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to Western Esotericism, particularly Qabalah, as it meticulously outlines the Zoharic paradigm shift where ongoing mystical experience and direct divine vision are not historical relics but living, attainable states through textual engagement. It redefines prophecy, legitimizing new insights by collapsing the traditional chasm between ancient revelation and contemporary gnosis. This concept provides a foundational framework for many subsequent Qabalistic and magical systems that emphasize visualization, inner light work, and the manipulation of divine names/energies through sacred texts. The paper implicitly establishes the Zohar as not just a commentary but a new revelation, thereby setting a precedent for other esoteric texts that claim revelatory status through interpretation. It underpins practices where the study of sacred texts is itself a form of operative magic, transforming the practitioner into a conduit for divine flow.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is academic scholars of Jewish mysticism, Kabbalah, and the phenomenology of religious and esoteric experience. For practitioners of Western Esotericism, especially those engaged in Qabalistic or Hermetic traditions, it offers a sophisticated theoretical framework for understanding how textual work (e.g., contemplation of Hebrew letters, divine names, or symbolic diagrams) can be understood as a powerful form of visionary and unitive praxis, akin to prophetic revelation. It provides a deep dive into the underlying philosophy of how text-based magic can operate, offering context for techniques involving sacred language and script.
